div1.p: Special Orders #182 sentences Ryan, Jones, Gelhardt, and Lust to hard labor for joining in a mutiny. Included are notes by Hench. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 175 A 1900

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
Havana, October 16, 1900.

1. General Prisoner John Ryan, having been tried by a
general court-martial convened at Columbia Barracks, Cu-
ba, and found guilty of joining in a mutiny, in violation of
the 22d Article of War and of failure to give information
of a mutiny, in violation of the 23d Article of War, was
sentenced “To be confined at hard labor at such post as the
reviewing authority may direct for one (1) year.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 6, 1900, and
will be duly executed. Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
is designated as the place of confinement, to which point
the prisoner will be sent upon further orders from these
Headquarters.

2. General Prisoner Hartley Jones, having been tried by
a general court-martial convened at Columbia Barracks,
Cuba, and found guilty of disobedience of orders, in viola-
tion of the 21st Article of War, was sentenced “To be con-
fined at hard labor at such post as the reviewing authority may
direct, for six (6) months.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 6, 1900, and
will be duly executed. Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
is designated as the place of confinement, to which point
the prisoner will be sent upon further orders from these
Headquarters.

3. General Prisoner William G. Gelhardt, having been
tried by a general court-martial convened at Columbia
Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of joining in a mutiny,
in violation of the 22d Article of War, and failure to give
information of a mutiny, in violation of the 23d Article of
War, was sentenced “To be confined at hard labor at such
post as the reviewing authority may direct for one (1) year.

The sentence is confirmed to date October 15, 1900, and
will be duly executed. Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
is designated as the place of confinement, to which point
the prisoner will be sent upon further orders from these
Headquarters.

4. General Prisoner G. W. Lust, having been tried by a
general court-martial convened at Columbia Barracks, Cu-
ba, and found guilty of joining a mutiny, in violation of
the 22d Article of War, and failure to give information of
a mutiny, in violation of the 23d Article of War, was
sentenced. “To be confined at such post as the reviewing authority
may direct for one (1) year, the first seven (7) days of each month
to be solitary confinement on bread and water diet, and the
remaining days of each month to be at hard labor.”
